Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: I fixed it üòÑ

Author: YoYoO#2555
Content: `location.href = ("https://www.google.com/maps/search/"+position.coords.latitude+'+'+position.coords.longitude);`

Author: lexi#9144
Content: Does anyone know why my dropdown menu from bootstrap isn't dropping down

Author: lexi#9144
Content: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/dropdowns/

Author: lexi#9144
Content: I tried copying from there but it's not dropping down

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content:
@lexi as it says at the top of the dropdowns page, you need popper.js included before the bootstrap js.  Needed lines in head with spoilers (probably with some redundant bootstrap js but I wouldn't know which to remove):

||<script href="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/popper.js/1.11.0/umd/popper.min.js" type="text/javascript"></script>||
(I constructed this from the popper.min.js link on the dropdowns page)
||<script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.2.1.slim.min.js" integrity="sha384-KJ3o2DKtIkvYIK3UENzmM7KCkRr/rE9/Qpg6aAZGJwFDMVNA/GpGFF93hXpG5KkN" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>||
||<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/popper.js/1.12.9/umd/popper.min.js" integrity="sha384-ApNbgh9B+Y1QKtv3Rn7W3mgPxhU9K/ScQsAP7hUibX39j7fakFPskvXusvfa0b4Q" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>||
||<script src="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.0.0/js/bootstrap.min.js" integrity="sha384-JZR6Spejh4U02d8jOt6vLEHfe/JQGiRRSQQxSfFWpi1MquVdAyjUar5+76PVCmYl" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>||
(Copied direct from the get started page of the bootstrap site (which would be where you could have redundant code))

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: Just because I don't like giving the answer just like that, I thought I would mention how I figured it out. I inspected the element on the dropdowns page, and saw that it was exactly the same.  Then I noticed that when I was clicking the dropdown button, the html was changing.  So I knew there was some kind of interactive process not found just in the html/css, and then I finally checked the documentation properly.

Author: lexi#9144
Content: THanks!

Author: hisfastness#2258
Content: Does anyone else find the web stuff to be a bit less exciting than what we did with C and Python? I'm just on homepage right now, but to me this feels like a lot of trial and error to get CSS right. C and Python required more computational logic.

Author: hisfastness#2258
Content: Switching between HTML, CSS, Javascript breaks me out of the focus I found myself in with C and Python. I dunno, maybe its because this is new. Or front-end stuff isn't my thing.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
It is great in the sense that you can have visible results with very little code, and trivial examples don't even require a build system.
But in general, I do prefer backend stuff. It feels so much more well-defined, even though network isn't exactly that.

Author: Dalsnin#3322
Content: @hisfastness I love it. It is very clear to see changes and improvements, whereas python and C is way more abstract.

Author: drail159#6376
Content: @Dalsnin But there is something attractive about that abstraction. There is something I find very appealing about an algorithm structured to do a specific job but abstract enough for any potential use case. But I'm glad that people see things your way because otherwise we wouldn't have front-end developers.

Author: Dalsnin#3322
Content: @drail159 I agree üôÇ

Author: L.S.#6002
Content: Hey I have a question. If you have code that will repeat itself in every page of your site, isn‚Äôt there a way to save that code to a separate html file and just import/link it to every page of your site instead of repeating it in every file?

Author: L.S.#6002
Content: For example, a side bar

Author: chriso#1172
Content: You can make templates using wordpress or javascript templating software like mustache.js but I dont think you need to worry about that for this because you have to learn more than just html js and css

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: L.S., the finance pset will do that using something called Flask, which is implementing a kind of language in html called JINJA.  basically you will have a template html file, with a couple of blocks set aside to accept more content, and then other html files will say "extends template" and then define what is in the missing blocks.

Author: L.S.#6002
Content: @Sinergy good to know. Thanks!

Content: Something like `margin: 0 auto;` maybe?

Content: On the div? Now that's confusing, I think I understood it wrong.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Blauelf#6622
Content: So `mx-auto` would expect an element with `display:block;`, while images are `display:inline;` by default.

Content: @Franciscosta Your homepage project looks sweet!

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: How did you get the code hosted? I'm not really sure how that side really works yet like buying a domain name / how you set up the code to be active on a server

Author: Mievo#6594
Content: You need webspace (on a webserver) and a domain that will then point to the ip-address of the server. The server catches the request and will direct it to the folder, so for instance to "mywebsite/". And insinde the mywebsite/ folder you have for instance index.html, main.css and main.js.

Author: Mievo#6594
Content: @MaxMayo

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: So the webserver hosts the code, while the domain name is linked to the IP address so people can request your pages ?

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: @Mievo

Author: Mievo#6594
Content: Yes, in easy words

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: Thanks for explaining that for me! Lol learning something new everyday

Author: Mievo#6594
Content: No problem, you're welcome!

Author: Mievo#6594
Content: You could also google e.g. nameserver, http request, how does a domain work, what is a webserver to find more and detailed information (y)

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: I'll definitely do that, all that stuff is super useful. I'm gonna try and set up my own homepage similarly

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Thank you @MaxMayo ! My url is on iwantmyname.com, I then do the DNSs in cloudflare and host the app on heroku.com. The app is just a bunch of static HTML / CSS / JS files. I learned a little hack here: https://blog.teamtreehouse.com/deploy-static-site-heroku for how to do it. (Had no idea the Flask video was literally going to be about making a to-do list ahah).

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Lastly, your to-dos persist because I stored them in the browser (localStorage).

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Spent a week basically watching youtube and reading stackoverflow to figure it all out / learn how to access storage via JS, etc..

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Hope that helps!!

Author: MaxMayo#4771
Content: That's awesome! I have some googling to do ahahah, definitely an awesome implementation of what we've learned so far + above and beyond

Author: Franciscosta#2924

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: Totally worth it!

Author: Franciscosta#2924
Content: To spend time on it.

Content: I reckon literally google: How to upload static site onto Heroku

Author: Thanos A#8843
Content: this exercise is really satisfying to me as I am rookie in web dev

Author: Thanos A#8843
scoobie#7439
Content:
```
<!DOCTYPE html>

<html lang="en">
    <head>
        <title>
            Hello!
        </title>
        <script>
            function greet()
            {
                let name = document.querySelector('#name').value();
                alert('Hello, ' + name + '!');
            }
        </script>
    </head>
    <body>
        <form onsubmit="greet(); return false;">
            <input type="text" id="name">
            <input type="submit">
        </form>
    </body>
</html>
```

Author: Charles#0217
Content: Design mobile first!

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: I go back and forth on the mobile first design the more I think about it. If you look at statistics, about 50% of internet traffic worldwide is on mobile. So about 50/50. Going forward that number will likely keep increasing though so I lean toward the mobile first mindset... however as of right now it is almost 50/50

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: That said, it‚Äôs not particularly difficult to make your pages responsive so they look good on all screen sizes. I‚Äôm not a huge Bootstrap fan but since this assignment calls for it, it makes the responsive design even easier

Author: Charles#0217
Content: the mobile first mindset isn't completely because the world is moving towards majority mobile visitors

Author: Charles#0217
Content: If you design for the smallest viewport, yes you hit the majority of screens first, but your work is far less this way as well, for example you use less media queries.

Author: Charles#0217
Content: I haven't build a web app in awhile but one of the things that helped me alot too was learning em and rem instead of px to size my text. It works really well when adjusting for screen sizes and shortens your css. Also sass is a really great technology to use and it relatively easy to learn.

Author: krinetic#7212
Content: what are ur guys thought on boostrap

Author: Charles#0217
Content: It‚Äôs good for getting something up and running quickly. But it‚Äôs also very easy to spot a website that utilized bootstrap.

Author: Charles#0217
Content: It makes navs super easy so that‚Äôs a big plus

Author: MiDO#7198
Content: Is this pset (and the next one) manually evaluated?

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: @krinetic Meh. It‚Äôs good for quick prototyping but so many sites use it now that it makes them all look the same. Straight up custom CSS is more time consuming obviously but at least it‚Äôs all custom and not so cookie-cutter. Flexbox and Grid make it so you can handle your grid/columns through plain old vanilla css.

Author: Huskabyte#9058
Content: Does it really matter if it's noticeable or not? As long as you have smooth UI it shouldn't matter what you used ~~other than if you used wix or some website builder because those are a scam~~

Author: Charles#0217
Content: Well it doesn't really matter, but just like pbrouse said, so many sites look so similar because of them. If you go onto a website that uses bootstrap you can almost always immediatly tell that they are.

Author: Charles#0217
Content: I'm not dissing bootstrap at all, that's just my thoughts. It's a great tool, just like other CSS libraries like semantic UI

Author: pbrouse#8651
Content: Exactly. ‚ÄúDoes it matter‚Äù is a matter of opinion. Personally, I want what I build to be more unique than just another cookie cutter bootstrap layout. I find Bootstrap to look pretty dull. It is good at what it does, but it‚Äôs not really my preference. Personally I prefer plain old css.

Author: dougiedoom#1356
Content: Hey there. I've got a question on some of the guidance we've received on Homepage.

Author: dougiedoom#1356
Content: We're supposed to use some Bootstrap components, but we're also supposed to have our own stylesheet.

Author: dougiedoom#1356
Content: When we use Bootstrap, we're using Bootstrap's stylesheet. So is there a way to use both Bootstrap's stylesheet and our own for the same page, or do we need to split this up?

Author: dougiedoom#1356
Content: i.e., maybe have one page w/ bootstrap, and at least one page with our own stylesheet. is there a better solution, where I can provide the styling for some elements and bootstrap for others?

Author: dougiedoom#1356
Content: üëÜ That's Question 1

Content: Here's Question 2: I am finding some nice implementations of things on other websites. Like I like how a particular toggle switch between light and dark mode looks and functions on another website. Can I pull in the HTML & styling for that (with modification) if I build the JS myself, or is that a no-no? If I look at how W3 Schools implements something, can I reuse those?

Content: you can use both, just link your own stylesheet and the bootstrap as well.
